text: The Berkeley Political Review is a semesterly, nonpartisan political magazine and website founded at the University of California, Berkeley shortly after September 11th, 2001.Berkeley Political Review: About Berkeley Political Review. Retrieved 12 May 2020. Through printed publications and multimedia projects, the Review covers international and domestic political affairs. Submissions are limited; to write for, edit, or otherwise staff the magazine, undergraduate students must apply at the beginning of each semester.Berkeley Political Review: Apply Berkeley Political Review. Retrieved 12 May 2020. The Berkeley Political Review is notable for being the first journal based out of a public university to join the Alliance of Collegiate Editors, whose members include political reviews at Brown, Harvard, Stanford, and Columbia, among others.Barr, Sam. "ACE Interview with Rebiya Kadeer" Harvard Political Review. Retrieved 12 May 2020. Members of the Review have also hosted or co-hosted a number of debates, interviews, and panels, including engagements with Barbara Lee, Alex Chow, Sergio Fajardo, Richard Muller, Andrea Saul, and Dennis Prager."Rep. Barbara Lee visits campus for student town hall meeting" The Daily Californian. Retrieved May 13, 2020."Bearly Political Ep #1: Alex Chow and the Hong Kong Protests" Berkeley Political Review. Retrieved 13 May 2020."Conservative radio host Dennis Prager debates with UC Berkeley students on free speech" The Daily Californian. Retrieved 13 May 2020. ==Notable alumni== * Shane Goldmacher (editor), national political reporter for The New York Times; former chief White House correspondent for Politico."Profile: Shane Goldmacher" The New York Times. Retrieved 12 May 2020. * Christine Mai- Duc (editor), reporter for The Wall Street Journal; former staff writer for the Los Angeles Times."People: Christine Mai-Duc " The Los Angeles Times. Retrieved 12 May 2020."Alumni Profile: Christine Mai-Duc " UC Berkeley School of Journalism.
